text: Went to a certain bank for the third time for the same problem.  What is the point in apologizing and grovelling about their utter incompetence when they do not take any actions ot fix it (reporting to supervisor, better training, fixing bugs in computer systems, contacting customer service representatives).   I needed a new card since January 2010 and it is now June and I still have not received it. I called the number on the back of the card, I went in person 3 times and spoke to my bank manager.  Consistently, I have asked for it to be mailed to my apartment in Montreal.  The bank I went to is located at McGill College in Montreal and it has been giving me a big headache.  I went in to see the tellers in person to get everything resolved and so far, I had the pleasure of taking unpaid time off work and speaking to 3 representatives who kept promising to fix the problem.  It is June and I am still waiting for my card and I have taken my last day I can afford from my personal time to address this company's incompetent system/staff and it is not a good use of my time and energy.  I strongly advise they fix this problem before further damaging their reputation. I already took the time to come in 3 times and spoke to 3 people - not including the time I spent on hold over the telephone.  Today, I went in and was furious.  I think I almost made that trainee teller cry.  Seriously, dealing with people's incompetence is a huge pet peeve of mine.  In marketing research, they say that for every good service you receive, the customer is likely to promote it 4 people and for every bad service, the word of mouth would spread to about 10. I hope at least these bad companies get a slap to the wrist and learn their lesson.  If a child can learn a simple lesson about making others feel bad, surely employees with fancy degrees can too.

Triste de comparer la Banque HSBC du Canada à HSBC aux USA. Nous avons choisi il y a quelque années d'ouvrir notre compte d'entreprise chez HSBC, principalement parce que l'on fait des affaires internationalement  (petit chiffre d'affaire, mais international) et que HSBC a une réputation pour leurs transactions internationales.  Le processus d'ouverture a pris quelques mois pour avoir des comptes de compagnie au Canada et aux États-Unis, beaucoup de papier et de va-et-viens. Finalement, nos comptes ont été opérationnels vers la fin de 2010.  Depuis, je dois dire que j'ai un service impeccable avec HSBC aux État-Unis (ma succursale est sur la 5e avenue à New York). Les chèques déposé dans les succursales (principalement par courrier à Beverly Hills) et aux guichet automatiques ne sont JAMAIS gelés, même les chèques personnels... les fonds sont disponibles le lendemain de la transaction tout simplement. Le compte est sans frais et j'ai même droit à six "wire transfers" internationaux par mois sans frais. Les transactions en ligne se font très bien et la carte de débit porte le sceau "Master Card" qui permet de l'utiliser simplement dans le monde. De plus, j'ai un chargé de compte assigné que je peut rejoindre aisément.  Comparativement, le service au Canada de HSBC est pathétique. Le compte comporte des frais sur la plupart des services, tout dépôt au guichet est gelé pour cinq jours ouvrables (y compris le comptant), la carte de débit n'est utilisable qu'au Canada et le service est anonyme (plus de chargé de compte assigné. On appelle le service général). De plus, (et c'est la goutte d'eau qui a fait débordé le vase et inspiré ce "review") j'ai fait un dépôt au comptoir aujourd'hui d'un chèque du Gouvernement du Québec et on me l'a gelé pour 5 jours ouvrables! Bien sûr, le Gouvernement du Québec, c'est suspect. Un peu comme Chypre peut-être?  Vraiment, tout cela, et toute la différence provient théoriquement de la même banque et cela concerne exactement la même petite entreprise dans les deux cas. Vraiment, je n'ai pas d'expérience comparable avec d'autres banques, mais je trouve cela vraiment insultant de voir comment on est traité au Canada par HSBC.

WORST HSBC bank EVER. I have traveled all over the world and have multiple HSBC accounts in different parts of the world, so I thought it would be a good idea to have one here (considering my past experience has always been superb). Boy was that a mistake! Not only are the representatives at the bank SLOW and quite frankly, dumb, but I feel like I am a criminal every time I enter HSBC!   Not only that, I was recently blocked from my account through a telephone representative because I was trying to pay for a bill online and needed help, because apparently all the 2020 questions that they asked did not match my identification answers.   So something that should have been easy, ended up being difficult and more work since now I have to go to the bank with two identification cards because I WAS BLOCKED FROM MY OWN ACCOUNT.   HSBC is unrealistically difficult and they criminalize their own customers with bad service.
